results.title: Herb Elliott says 'Take five and stay alive'
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Cinesound
results.brief_description: Herb Elliott is shown breaking the four minute mile and discussing his training. Just as poor training and condition can cause an injury which will put a runner out for the season, so a faulty motor and bad driving can put a driver and others out, perhaps for life.
results.title_for_label: Herb Elliott says ‘Take five and stay alive’

results.title: Hephzibah
results.brief_description: A documentary about Hephzibah Menuhin, sister of acclaimed violinist Yehudi, who led her own remarkable life. In 1938 when she was eighteen she abandoned a promising career as a concert pianist in the United States to marry Lindsay Nicholas, Australian heir to the Aspro fortune, moving to his remote sheep station. Following the War, Hephzibah toured Europe and had a scandalous affair with Viennese sociologist Richard Hauser. Moved by the horrors of the concentration camps, she became increasingly isolated from her privileged life in Australia. She left her husband and children, married Hauser and settled in London where the couple established their Centre for Human Rights. The documentary utilises archival home movie footage, Hephzibah’s letters and music from her performances to gain insight into the decisions she made throughout her life.

results.title: Henry V [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Kenneth Branagh, Bruce Sharman, BBC and Renaissance Films
results.brief_description: Henry V, young king of medieval England, roused his troops to arms against a French army five times greater than themselves. His life and leadership was legendary. From the above story, William Shakespeare wrote one of his greatest plays. Kenneth Branagh, whose stage portrayal of Henry V has been world-acclaimed, made his film directorial debut with this film. Also starring Paul Scofield, Derek Jacobi, Judi Dench and Christian Bale, the film loses none of the power and beauty of Shakespeare’s text.

results.title: Henrik Ibsen
results.creator_credit: Nigel Wattis and London Weekend Television
results.brief_description: Narrated by Michael Meyer, this discussion of the controversial career of playwright, Henrik Ibsen, covers both biographical details of the writer and delineates the four significant stages in his writing through a comprehensive study of the themes and the sociological and political impact of his work and its part in changing the face of live theatre. His characteristic questioning of authority and tradition and demands for debate on issues in wider society through his work is evoked and discussed. As is the powerful turning point in theatre his approach to writing and acting influenced, with discussion of his scripts about ordinary people that turned theatre into a mirror on society and encouraged relational acting instead of grand solo performances in larger than life show pieces that had previously dominated the theatrical scene. Through the program’s commentary, interviews with other writers and academics, through readings of his work, including his letters and diaries, and excerpts from performances of his renowned plays this documentary provides a thorough analysis of the influential work of Henrik Ibsen as well as a contextual insight into the more personal life of this powerful writer.

results.title: Hen hop (TEFC)
results.brief_description: A cartoon film in which a hen, sometimes a Leghorn, at other times a Plymouth Rock, and even an egg with feet, dance to the old time waltzes and reels of French-Canadian barn dance music. A cartoon film hand-drawn with pen and ink by Norman McLaren, with colour added optically. Used to publicise a Victory Bond drive.

results.title: Helping our boys help themselves
results.brief_description: One of the most hotly debated subjects in educational circles worldwide is the trouble many boys are having with traditional schooling and growing up in general. This program provides some practical and desperately needed examples of how two diverse secondary schools are helping their boys to help themselves. Boort Secondary College, a small, country Victorian school where the academic performance and social growth of boys is encouraged through the Building blokes program. Cleeleand Secondary College, a large, tough school in a disadvantaged and multicultural outer Melbourne suburb which helps its boys with the Gateway Project and Make a difference program. An excellent follow up program to “The Trouble with boys”. Study guide included.

results.title: Helpful Henry
results.brief_description: City boy spends summer on a farm and seems to think they should change their way of living. He has his own ideas about how things work, but eventually finds he is wrong and needs to learn from others.

results.title: Help yourself to better health
results.creator_credit: Jamil Simon and Jamil Simon Productions
results.brief_description: This film illustrates how good nutrition is possible with limited budgets, varying food habits, and different cooking facilities. A trip through a supermarket with an older person demonstrates how older people can shop wisely and nutritionally.

results.title: Help yourself - self employment (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Self-employed people describe their work and explain why they are self employed. Their occupations vary from handyman, stallholders, to a proprietor of a chain of jeans stores. All of these businesses started with relatively small amounts of capital. The video also outlines essential steps to be taken by people considering self-employment and lists contacts who can give useful advice.
